data.name: Vitamin B1
data.description: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamin, is a water-soluble vitamin essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function. It supports energy production and is critical for maintaining healthy nerve cells and heart function.

intakePractices.dosage: Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for adults is 1.1-1.2 mg/day. Supplements typically provide 50-100 mg for therapeutic use.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day, preferably with a meal to enhance absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: High doses should be used under medical supervision to avoid potential side effects. Store in a cool, dry place.

sideEffects: High doses may cause mild upset stomach

studies.title: Thiamin supplementation and energy metabolism
studies.summary: Confirmed role in carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function.

data.name: Vitamin B2
data.description: Vitamin B2, also known as riboflavin, is a water-soluble vitamin crucial for energy metabolism, red blood cell formation, and maintaining healthy skin and eyes. It supports cellular energy production and antioxidant activity.

intakePractices.dosage: Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for adults is 1.1-1.3 mg/day. Supplements typically provide 25-100 mg for therapeutic use.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken with a meal to improve absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: High doses may cause yellowing of urine, which is harmless. Consult a doctor for prolonged high-dose use.

sideEffects: Excessive doses may cause mild diarrhea

studies.title: Riboflavin and cellular energy production
studies.summary: Demonstrated role in energy metabolism and antioxidant protection.

data.description: Raw fish contains thiaminases, enzymes that degrade thiamin, reducing its bioavailability.
data.recommendation: Avoid consuming raw fish when taking Vitamin B1 supplements to ensure optimal absorption.
sources: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements, Talbott & Hughes, 2007

data.description: Magnesium enhances the conversion of thiamin into its active form, thiamin pyrophosphate, improving its efficacy.
data.recommendation: Consider taking Vitamin B1 with magnesium supplements for improved metabolic effects.
sources: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements, Talbott & Hughes, 2007

data.description: Dairy products are naturally rich in riboflavin and can complement supplementation, improving overall intake.
data.recommendation: Take Vitamin B2 supplements with dairy products, if tolerated, to enhance absorption.
sources: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements, Talbott & Hughes, 2007

data.description: Iron supplementation may improve riboflavinâ€™s role in red blood cell production, supporting anemia treatment.
data.recommendation: Combine Vitamin B2 with iron supplements if addressing iron-deficiency anemia, under medical supervision.
sources: The Health Professional's Guide to Dietary Supplements, Talbott & Hughes, 2007
